titleStmt.title: Scaling in global tidal dissipation of the Earth-Moon system

analytic.title: Scaling in global tidal dissipation of the Earth-Moon system

biblStruct.note: Accepted XXX. Received YYY; in original form ZZZ
Compiled using MNRAS L A T E X style file v3.0

abstract.p: The Moon migrated to r ≃ 3.8 × 10 10 cm over a characteristic time r/v = 10 10 Gyr by tidal interaction with the Earth's oceans at a present velocity of v = 3.8 cm yr −1. We derive scaling of global dissipation that covers the entire history over the past 4.52 Gyr. Off-resonance tidal interactions at relatively short tidal periods in the past reveal the need for scaling with amplitude. The global properties of the complex spatio-temporal dynamics and dissipation in broad spectrum ocean waves is modeled by damping ǫ = hF/(2Q 0), where h is the tidal wave amplitude, F is the tidal frequency, and Q 0 is the Q-factor at the present time. It satisfies Q 0 ≃ 14 for consistency of migration time and age of the Moon consistent with observations for a near-resonance state today. It shows a startingly fast eviction of the Moon from an unstable near-synchronous orbit close to the Roche limit, probably in a protolunar disk. Rapid spin down of the Earth from an intial ∼ 30% of break-up by the Moon favored early formation of a clement global climate. Our theory suggests moons may be similarly advantageous to potentially habitable exoplanets.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Over the past eons, tidal interaction produced a major evolution of the Earth-Moon system, producing a relatively slowly rotating planet down from about one-third of centrifugal break-up at birth, very similar then to Jupiter's state today. For a detailed discussion on the break-up angular velocity Ω b ≃ GM /R 3 of a planet of mass M and radius R, see, e.g., Davidsson (1999).

Tidal interactions are inherently dissipative, determined by a phase-lag between tidal deformation and position of the perturber, i.e., a misalignment of tidal bulge relative to the Earth-Moon direction. For the Earth, dissipation is primarily in the ocean tidal flows, more so than viscoelastic deformation of the Earth's mantle (e.g. Munk 1968; Garrett & Munk 1971;Lambeck 1977;Dickey et al. 1994;Ray 1994;Ray et al. 1996;Efroimsky & Williams 2009;Efroimsky 2012Efroimsky , 2015, whose seismic frequencies are relative high compared to the tidal frequency (Love 1911;Munk & MacDonald 1960;Dahlen 1974) with the exception of those driven by ocean waves (Webb 2007). However, a detailed quantitative account for the overall Moon's migration time due to various nonlinear dissipation channels (Stoker 1948(Stoker , 1957Munk 1968;Egbert & Ray 2001), remains to be identified.

⋆ E-mail: mvp@sejong.ac.kr Tidal dissipation (Garrett & Munk 1971;Webb 1982;Dickey et al. 1994) has various mechanisms in shallow water wave theory, some of which have recently been highlighted in detailed numerical simulations on ocean dynamics and dissipation covering relatively short initial and present epochs (e.g Touma & Wisdom 1994Egbert & Ray 2004;Stammer et al. 2014). Dissipation generally occurs when nonlinear steepening exceeds the mitigating effect of dispersion. Determining the net global result from detailed modeling of tidal dissipation is particularly challenging by the diversity of oceans and coastal regions, where most of the dissipation is expected to occur (Miller 1966;Garrett & Munk 1971).

Here, we focus on scaling in both amplitude and frequency of global tidal dissipation to account for the EarthMoon history over the past 4.52 Gyr. This approach aims at providing an effective description of an otherwise complex spatio-temperal distribution of dissipation in broadband ocean waves. For a confrontation with data, the Moon's migration time is computed by numerical integration of angular momentum transfer backwards in time, to the instant of its formation from the Earth or a surrounding protolunar disk. This approach enables taking into account variations in tidal implitude over a few orders of magnitude, the effect of which seems not to have been computed before. The evolution by coupling to the Earth's spin (e.g. Efroimsky & Williams 2009) is conveniently described by the orbital angular momentum m GM (1 − e 2 )a with semimajor axis a, where m = 7.35 × 10 22 g and M = 5.97 × 10 27 g denote the mass of the Moon and, respectively, Earth. The orbital ellipticity e is presently about 5.5%. A large dynamic range in tidal interaction strength arises from the tidal amplitude h ∝ r −3 by which the Moon's specific angular momentum at radius r ≃ a evolves according to

where ∆ϕ is the phase-lag of the Moon's orbit relative to the tide raised on the Earth, and r −3 is the mutual interaction strength for a given h. As a result, dj/dt ∝ r −6 (cf. Efroimsky & Williams 2009). To begin, we first recall some general conditions for dissipation in ocean tidal flows ( §2). In §3, we formulate our scaling of dissipation in tidal amplitude and frequency. It serves to parameterize damping in our model based on (1) and the pendulum equation ( §4). This model is explored numerically in §5. In §6, we summarize the results.

div.head: SOME CONDITIONS FOR TIDAL DISSIPATION
div.p: While the theory of linear shallow water waves is dissipationless, finite amplitude waves can steepen to dissipative bores, provided that steeping exceeds the mitigating effect of dispersion. The degree of nonlinearity over dispersion is expressed by Ursell number U r = hλ 2 /d 3 , by the amplitude h and wave length λ ( Ursell 1953;Munk 1968;Barthélemy 2004)

here specialized to shallow water waves with propagation speed c = √ gd in oceans of depth d at tidal period P , where g = 9.8 m s −2 is the Earth's gravitational acceleration. While, a large Ursell number is suggestive of a general tendency for wave breaking, it does not directly define scaling of dissipation. For breaking to occur, steepening must be sufficiently fast (e.g. Munk 1968) (see Levinson & van Putten (1997) for a discussion in Burgers' equation with time-dependent forcing). In nonlinear wave motion (cf. Whitham 1974), it results from steepening after a time

(For a more detailed discussion, see Stoker (1957 The dissipation rate of bores produced by wave breaking satisfies entropy creation in shocks of compressible gas dynamics, i.e., scaling with the cube of their amplitude. By aforementioned h ∝ r −3 , wave breaking, by either (2) or (4), provides a time rate of dissipation effectively described by damping proportional to h, possibly including tidal frequency in light of broadband wave spectra. Our approach is focused on scaling in global dissipation described by (6), to capture the net result of an otherwise complex spatiotemporal distribution of dissipation in the Earth's oceans.

div.head: AMPLITUDE-FREQUENCY SCALING OF DISSIPATION
div.p: We set out model global tidal dissipation in the Earth's oceans by (1) in dimensionless variables, normalized by today's Moon migration data and age. The tidal amplitude h is described by a damped linear pendulum equation with eigenfrequency ω0, forced at semi-diurnal tidal frequency ω ′ by the action of the Moon at orbital angular velocity ω,
where Ω denotes the angular velocity of the Earth. The damping coefficient ǫ in the pendulum equation represents dissipation with associated phase lag ∆ϕ and Q-factor Q = 1/(2ǫ).
To study the net result over the entire history of the Earth-Moon system, we consider the general scaling in amplitude h and dimensionless tidal frequency F ,

and its confrontation with data for various choices of p, q = 0, 1. With (6), we aim to capture the net result of tidal amplitude-frequency dependence that covers weak and strong interactions at present and, respectively, back in the distant past. In the Stokes' limit p = q = 0, for instance, and ignoring resonances, integration of (1) backwards in time obtains a migration time on the order of 1 Gyr at odds with the Moon's age (cf. Gerstenkorn 1955;Goldreich 1966;Munk 1968). This suggests that tidal dissipation is anomalously high at present. (Equivalently, the Q-factor was higher in the past, e.g., (Touma & Wisdom 1998).) Taking into account the inertial range off-resonance in the past (Fig. 1), however, one is led to the opposite conclusion with a previously low Q-factor, here revisited by numerical integration of (1) with (6) in the forced pendulum equation.
The Moon migrated to its present mean distance r = 3.8 × 10 10 cm with a radial velocity v = 3.8 cm yr −1 (Bills & Ray 1999). It defines a characteristic migration time scale

that will serve to express the equation of motion (1) in terms of a dimensionless time t/tm ( §3 below). Being tidally locked, the Moon spins slowly with negligible angular momentum. By now, the Earth's spin has effectively been transferred to the Earth-Moon orbit, since

based on the Moon's mass m ≃ M/81, the Earth's angular momentum IΩ, radius R = 6 × 10 8 and moment of Goldreich 1966;Romanowicz & Dambeck 1977). The present-day tidal deformation h0 (in cm) has a characteristic scale defined by the zero-frequency perturbation of the Newtonian binding energy UN of self-gravity and Ut in the Moon's tidal field, δU b = GM 2 R −3 h 2 0 , δUt = GmM Rr −3 h0, which recovers the familiar scaling
div.formula: h0 = R r 3 m M R ≃ 30 cm (9)
div.p: with δU b = δUt ≃ 8 × 10 24 erg, consistent with existing estimates on ocean tide energies (Garrett & Munk 1971) and measured mean values of the dynamical tidal amplitude h to about 20% (Miller 1966;Wahr 1995). Consistency of h0 with dynamical tidal amplitude is somewhat coincidental in view of the relatively minor deformation of the Earth's mantle (Wahr 1995) and an appreciable Q-factor in the ocean tides (e.g. Webb 1982). By the first law of thermodynamics, the Earth's rotational energy Erot = 1 2 IΩ 2 is deposited into the Moon's orbit, H ≃ −GM m/(2a) and heat, the latter by tidal dissipation in the Earth

i.e., about 6.6 mW m −2 , where 1TW=10 12 Watt inferred from the time rate-of-change in the angular momentum J = mj of the Moon (Garrett & Munk 1971;Webb 1982;Dickey et al. 1994). Presently, Ω/ω ≃ 30, whereby Erot is mostly dissipated into heat, powering H at merely three percent efficiency. In the Earth's tides, estimates of associated Q-factor (e.g. MacDonald 1964;Goldreich & Soter 1966;Munk 1968;Goldreich 1966;Garrett & Munk 1971;Tyler 2008) satisfy
for the present-day semidiurnal tidal period P ≃ 12 hr.

Our starting point to model tidal dissipation driving (1) is the theory of forced damped pendulum equation with damping (6). At present, tidal forcing appears to be near its resonance frequency ω0 with tidal ocean flows effectively described by the theory of shallow water waves (Pekeris & Accad 1969;Gerstenkorn 1955;Goldreich 1966;Hansen 1982;Webb 1982;Platzman 1981). While this gives rise to the presently strong Earth-Moon coupling close to resonance, this tidal interaction was effectively off-resonance in most of the past (Webb 1982;Hansen 1982) when tidal frequencies were higher. Thus, the Earth-Moon tidal interaction has been rolling-up towards resonance in the inertial range with forcing gradually approaching the ocean tidal eigenfrequency, shown in Fig. 1 as a trajectory of amplitude h versus ω ′ /ω0. Fig. 1 further shows a window of values ω ′ /ω0 today, permitted by integration over the past 4.52 Gyr with scalings (6), shown in Section 4 below.

The damping coefficient can also be expressed in terms of the decay time τ d = 1/ǫω0. For instance, ǫ = 0.07, corresponds to a decay time of about 30 hours (Hendershott & Munk 1970;Webb 1982) with corresponding present-day Q0 ≃ 7 (cf. MacDonald 1964;Garrett & Munk 1971;Webb 1973). With tidal forcing mostly off-resonance in the past, in the inertial range of Table 1 lists the most pertinent variables used in our analysis. Dimensionless variables assume the value 1 at present by normalization to today's values. The exception is the look back time
where t0 denotes the present time, for use in numerical integration with the property that τ = 0 now and τ = 0.452 at the time of birth of the Moon.

div.head: FORCED DAMPED PENDULUM EQUATION
div.p: The tidal excitation h(t) (cm) can be described by the damped linear pendulum equation
div.formula: ¨ h(t) + 2iǫω0 ˙ h(t) + ω 2 0 h(t) = ω 2 0 A sin(ω ′ t),(13)
div.p: where A refers to the tidal interaction strength and h0 in (9) provides a scale for h(t) today, but not in the distant past. Forcing of the quadrupole tidal deformation has strength A ∝ r −3 and frequency (5). Shown in Fig. 1, (13) features distinct limits to the left or right of its eigenfrequency ω0 of phase-lag ∆ϕ (and hence dissipation), proportional to ǫ(ω/ω0) and ǫ(ω0/ω) at low, respectively, high frequency. The amplitude approaches a constant or decays with (ω0/ω) 2 in the same two limits. For a dimensionless equation of motion, we define the normalized tidal frequency (5) with F (j) = 1 at present j = 1 conform (8). Thus, F (j) and j represent (5) upon dividing by their respective presentday values. Table 1 lists some of the variables and their normalizations. For the purpose of our discussion and in light of e << 1 today, we here specialize to circular orbits (r ≡ a), ignoring a possibly large ellipticity at the initial stage from early resonances (Touma & Wisdom 1998;Frouard et al. 2010).

div.p: As a function of the look back time (12), the evolution (1) in dimensionless specific angular momentum j satisfies the initial value problem
where p = sin(2∆ϕ)/ sin(2∆ϕ0) and Z = z/z0 with ∆ϕ = tan −1 (V / |U |) and
0 F , normalized by the present values ∆ϕ0 and z0 at τ = 0 (j = 1). Here,
denotes the ratio of tidal frequency to ocean eigenfrequency today.
Evolution (15) has stationary points at the two zeros of F (j),

in the past and, respectively, future when Ω = ω (synchronous orbits, F (j) = 0) with vanishing leading order semidiurnal tidal interaction. They are, respectively, unstable at 2.56R, essentially the Roche lobe distance to the Earth, and stable at about 100R. Our model, therefore, describes migration over a finite distance r. Normalized to r at present, it covers

Our focus is on Eqn. (15) integrated backwards in time, from j = 1 at present down to j0, at the onset of migration. Future development towards the synchronous state j1 fall outside the scope of this work; cf. the synchronous PlutoCharon system. ( Farinella et al. 1979;Taylor & Margot 2011;Cheng et al. 2014;Taylor & Margot 2014). To complete (13), we next turn to ǫ and consistency of migration time and the Moon's age, estimated to be 4.53 ± 0.01 Gyr ( Kleine et al. 2005) and 4.48 ± 0.02 Gyr (Halliday 2008).

div.head: NUMERICAL RESULTS
div.p: The Q-factor (11), Q0 = 1/2ǫ0, of the present-day EarthMoon tidal interaction is observationally constrained to (cf. Hendershott & Munk 1970;Webb 1982;MacDonald 1964;Garrett & Munk 1971;Webb 1973) 5 < Q0 < 30, 0.017 < ǫ0 < 0.100.
We now integrate (15) over 4.52 Gyr (τ = 0.452) to reach a fiducial state ω ′ 0 /ω0 = 1.11 of near-resonance at present. The required dissipation is compared with (19).

Linear theory described by constant ǫ = ǫ0 requires ǫ = 0.1365. Its anomalously low Q0 = 3.7 points to the need for enhanced damping in the past. As pointed to by the large Ursell numbers (2), we consider entropy creation Figure 4. The Ursell number was larger in the past, except for a 5% dip from its current value when the Moon as 5% closer. Nonlinear dissipation by wave breaking appears important for all of the Earth's tidal history with some suppression in the inertial range ω ′ >> ω 0 also due to a reduced phase angle ∆ϕ. Close to j 0 , our model breaks down by essentially divergent Ursell numbers.
in bores formed by steepening scaled by the cube of tidal amplitude, i.e., damping with tidal amplitude scaling

A maximum of 1 is imposed for large amplitude waves, losing essentially all their energy in one cycle. Integration of (15) with (20) recovers a migration time equal to the Moon's age with Q0 = 9.5, ǫ0 = 0.0527.

The transition to ǫA = 1 in (20) is reached at 38% of r . It should be mentioned that the results are extremely insensitive to the choice of maximum in (20). For instance, a maximum 2 gives ǫ0 = 0.0527368 instead of ǫ = 0.0527411 in (21). While (21) appears reasonable, the true Q-factor is conceivably larger.

Scaling characteristic of dissipation in broad spectrum wave motion further includes F , i.e., damping with tidal Table 2. Present-day damping coefficient ǫ 0 and Q-factor Q 0 in models of scaling with respect to tidal amplitude and frequency for consistency with the Moon's age of 4.52 Gyr with nearresonance today (ω ′ 0 /ω 0 = 1.11 amplitude-frequency scaling

representing increased wave breaking overall or enhancement in high amplitude waves with 1/P . This may derive from breaking over relatively short distances, e.g., before waves run ashore, or by flattening of ocean wave energy spectra. Without detailed numerical simulations, we resort to (15) for a confrontation with data. Intregration obtains a migration time of 4.52 Gyr with (Fig. 3) Q0 = 13.7, ǫ0 = 0.0366
consistent with (19). In this process, considerable suppression obtains by a reduction in phase ∆ϕ by a factor of about 3 at 75% of r (Fig. 4).
Alternative scaling with tidal frequency alone,

as in modeling turbulent viscosity, is substantially less effective than (20), requiring ǫ0 = 0.0860 (Q0 = 5.8) for a migration time of 4.52 Gyr. For (22), furthermore, Fig. 4 confirms that the Ursell number (2) was mostly larger in the past, except for a 5% drop at 95% of the current Moon distance. Table 2 summarizes these numerical observations. Fig. 5 shows the results across the full range of near-resonance states ω ′ 0 /ω0 today as permitted by our model. The trajectory of (15), illustrated in Fig. 1, with amplitude-frequency scaling (6) with p = q = 1 shows that most of the Moon's migration time is associated with the last 40% of its current distance. The first 60% is marked by a transition starting with a sharp spike, denoting rapid eviction of the Moon from j = j0. It results from an anomalously large tidal wave amplitude of a few km (essentially the current ocean depths), defined by h ≃ 1/j 12 0 in units of the present-day amplitue scale h0. Thus, dj/dτ = O 10 8 , giving an eviction time scale of about one hundred years out to tens of R. While this is unlikely accurate, e.g., tidal heating may have prevented water to condensate and may, instead, derive from a magma ocean ( Zahnle et al. 2015), the idea seems valid that, once oceans form, eviction is swift.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: The migration time of the Moon is determined by the rate of tidal dissipation, predominantly in tidal waves. In the past, forcing was mostly off-resonance in the inertial range above the resonance frequency ω0 in (13). Linear theory of dissipation described by the Stokes' limit ǫ = ǫ0 falls short of explaining a migration time equal to the Moon's age. Nonlinear dissipation mechanisms pointed to by (2) are important, now and even more so during off-resonance in the past.

Dissipation in bores is similar to that in shocks of compressible gas dynamics. The same is expected to feature spectral broadening and hardening by dispersion (e.g. Seabra-Santos 1985;Barthélemy 2004). Damping representing total tidal dissipation hereby is expected to scale both with tidal amplitude and frequency proposed in (22).

Total dissipation in the ocean tides contains also a component of internal dissipation by flows over non-smooth surfaces (Egbert & Ray 2000. It scales effectively with the cube of horizontal tidal flows (Gemmrich & Klymak 2015), akin to high Reynolds number flows past solid objects. According to the theory of shallow water wave equations, column height and height-averaged horizontal velocity satisfy the same wave equation in the linearized limit, the latter with amplitude

For harmonic perturbations, internal dissipation is equivalently described by damping proportional to u, and hence by h as a consequence of (25). In Table 2, this is included in the scaling by tidal amplitude. In scaling damping of ocean waves by hF , the same would be included approximately to within 30%. In considering (15) as an effective description of the dominant dissipation in semidiurnal tidal interactions, higher order tidal modes (Doodson 1921) are neglected with generally complex dependence on ocean basin geometry (Munk & Cartwright 1966). In a linearized approximation, one might contemplate including damping by higher harmonics. However, the latter are difficult to constrain observationally based on data of the Moon's migration velocity. Even if known, evolution of ocean basins on the geological time scale of 10 2 Myr (e.g. Wilson 1966Wilson , 1975) makes estimation of time-averages over a recent epoch highly uncertain. For this reason and the expectation that dissipation in the semi-diurnal tides are dominant, these higher order perturbations fall outside the scope of the present approach.

Numerical integration of (15) with (22) reproduces a Moon migration time equal to its age for a present Q-factor (23) in excellent agreement with the observational constraint (19). By (22), it introduces a dynamic Q-factor

that was substantially below Q0 = 1/(2ǫ0) in the past. Its trajectory features a startingly fast eviction of the Moon at or close to the initial, unstable synchronous orbit at j0. A protolunar disk with the same composition as the Earth (e.g. Barnes et al. 2014) might require even higher Earth spin rates prior, to facilitate its ejection by a giant impact (Canup & Asphaug 2001;Cuk & Stewart 2012). If so, the Moon is even more pertinent as a deposit of the Earth's initial spin angular momentum. Some uncertainty in the formulation of our model arises from the fact that the ocean eigenfrequency ω0 (closest to the semidiurnal tidal frequency) is that of the Atlantic ocean. By continental drift, it evolves on aforementioned geological time scale that, in particular, might include inter- hf-scaling h-scaling F-scaling Stokes limit Figure 5. Present-day Q-factor Q 0 in models of scaling with respect to tidal amplitude and frequency consistent with the Moon's age of 4.52 Gyr for various near-resonance conditions today, defined by tidal frequency ω ′ 0 over ocean eigenfrequency ω 0 at the present time. Solutions exist for a range 0.95 < ω ′ 0 /ω 0 < 1.35, that defines the vertical rectangle in Fig. 1. Values 13.4 < Q 0 < 20 attain for 1.01 < ω ′ 0 /ω 0 < 1.25 in evolution with ǫ scaled by both amplitude and frequency.

mittent closure (Wilson 1966(Wilson , 1975. In our numerical formulation, the present state then represents a time-average of a recent epoch, small relative to the Moon's age of 4.5 Gyr, probably satisfying

where the right hand side refers to today's instantaneous value. Here, we assume that during closure, ω0 is determined by the remaining oceans, also since Q of the Atlantic near closure is probably suppressed by inversion (uplift of the ocean basin; Wilson 1975)). In Fig. 5, (27) corresponds to moving along the ordinate to the right. By the relative flatness of the curves shown, our main conclusions hold, provided (27) remains in the window 0.95 < ω ′ ω0 < 1. 35 (28) for solutions to exist. Implications of larger perturbations fall outside the scope of the present formulation. Once oceans form, eviction of the Moon was swift with steep spindown of the Earth from what was very similar to that of Jupiter today. In contrast to Jupiter's extreme weather patterns ( Sommeria et al. 1988), our dramatically reduced spin with small Coriolis forces today facilitates a clement global climate. It is tempting to consider application of (22) further to exoplanet-moon systems (Kipping 2009;Ford et al. 2011;Schneider et al. 2001;EA 2016), whose selection is currently based on temperature, mass and size ( Méndez et al. 2006). Relatively distant moons may be indirect evidence for effective tidal interaction with oceans, further favoring a potentially clement climate conducive to advanced life.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Trajectory of the Earth-Moon system in the amplitudefrequency diagram of a forced pendulum with resonance frequency ω 0 of today's oceans. Starting from an unstable synchronous orbit with vanishing tidal angular frequency ω ′ , the trajectory reached a state of maximal tidal frequency in the inertial range ω ′ /ω 0 >> 1. As the Earth continued to spin down, the trajectory approached near-resonance today. The vertical rectangle indicates the domain of present state ω ′ 0 /ω 0 , that can be reached by integrating (15) over a period of 4.52 Gyr.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 2. Shown is the dimensionless tidal angular frequency 0 ≤ F (j) < 3 as a function of the dimensionless specific angular momentum j, satisfying j = 1 today. It features two stationary points at the roots F (j) = 0, corresponding to synchronous orbits Ω = ω.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. Numerical integration of (15) on the Moon migration with damping scaled by tidal amplitude-frequency (22), tidal amplitude (21) and constant damping for ǫ 0 = 0.0366 near-resonance at j = 1. Results are a function of look back time τ (t = τ tm) from j = 1 at τ = 0 up to the first critical point j 0 ≃ 0.2011 close to the Earth's Roche lobe distance.
